review:
Space Live - Advent of the Net Idols is a Visual Novel that focuses on 5 girls in this Idol world. With each of the 5 different spaces choosing a representative for this competition, the time has come to see which one will emerge victorious. There are multiple rounds they must do from singing to acting to capture the flag to find out who will win this Space Live.

The first thing to point of for this VN is that it is a kinetic visual novel. A kinetic visual novel does not have player choice implemented, meaning you will just go through the entire story without any choice. 

First the characters. Each of the five girls are based on different web browsers (G Chrome is obviously Google Chrome for example.) I like the variety of different colors of each of them, and the art is great. Sadly, we don't get many moments to see their character. The only one to get that is Ai at the start while the others get their introduction and how they interact with each other. The music is good, though I'm not one to know when music in a game is bad. However, I do think that sometimes, the music is repeated a few times. Also I do kinda wish there was voice acting seeing as there was a part where the characters had to sing. Also adding a little fan chat was charming.

There is one gripe I had with this VN. I know that this VN was kinetic(again, no player choice added), but it's a shame that [spoiler]After beating the bugs, we don't get a winner to this. After they beat the bugs, they say they are gonna do a victory song, and the game fades to black. Ai had to win this since this was her last chance as shown at the start, so not having a winner is just a little letdown for me.[/spoiler]

Overall, I enjoyed it and had a fun time reading it. If you want to get it, I highly recommend getting it on sale. It's kinda short and generic, but I definitely didn't waste time reading it. Wish it was a little longer.

P.S. There is some fanservice in this VN during the Capture the Flag competition where there are a few CGs involving [spoiler]wardrobe malfunctions that aren't censored[/spoiler]

review:
Overall, it's a very funny and pretty kinetic VN that delivers on bringing a fantastical idol competition to life. With its premise of a competition, you get to see quite a few interesting scenarios, like the "confession" part or the game of capture-the-flag-between-my-anime-tiddies. 

The humour of the girls being anthropomorphic web browsers were some of the best parts. I like how Tsukikage's name refers to her being a shadow of the past, and how Higitsune talks like a grandmother because Mozilla Firefox is an ancient browser. The character tensions are also pretty hilarious--the bickering between Higitsune and Tsukikage never failed to get a laugh out of me.

My only gripe is the lack of CGs for some events. They just described what was going on, and I feel like it was a great hindrance to the story-telling. I get that maybe E-mote was out of the budget, as well as *eden's every-frame-is-a-special-CG style, but could they really not get the artist to draw the action scene actually happening instead of a still of what was happening like 5 minutes ago? Compared to other VNs, it lacks in the presentation department and is a bit short (but at least it's not too long). I recommend buying during a sale than at full price.

I'm also a little peeved that they left out prime Idol material/targets of comedy such as Bing, Opera, Amazon Silk and Onyun. I guess they didn't have more room for idols. Such a shame...

review:
[i] Space Liveâ€”Advent of the Net Idols [/i] is a sweet relaxing novel. It's rather short but can be a nice choice for a light read on a weekend.

The best feature is undoubtedly art. It's so pretty, all CGs are very bright and attractive, neatly organized in a gallery. Unfortunately, there are no achievements but the game has trading cards. Badges and backgrounds are quite nice.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1719096800 
As for the story it's about five really cute idols representing different spaces. It was short but I found interesting that world description. Future generations abandon boring reality and indulge in exciting pastimes, for example, idol competitions which are held once in four years. We can watch a lighthearted though competitive interaction of attractive girls that can be easily recognized as main popular browsers. That's some crazy idea but portrayed really skillfully. 

That idol competition was a bit silly but still cute. I especially enjoyed their love confession contest with some touching bittersweet stories. So as a result we get a short but diverse well-balanced story on the whole.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1719265020 
Nothing is uncensored and there's no adult content or 18+ patch at all, just a possibility to gaze at their huge boobs in a rather suggestive outfit and swimsuits and some CGs with 'glorious swimsuit failure'. So it's not like completely innocent game for all ages. Oh my, someone, create already a game about a group of male idols. I have several visual novels about girl idols and their struggle and they are quite a nice way to relax but I often imagine how much more fun it'd be with the opposite sex. Welp, sorry for this tangent :) 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1719201228 
I enjoyed that little but absolutely amazing feature of fan chat. It creates a lovely illusion of immersion. I recollected all those live streams I used to watch myself.

It's a kinetic story but with the way it's ended I felt kinda involved [spoiler] because the final decision which girl is the best is left to a player [/spoiler].

The translation is good, at least for me as an ESL person. Though this story is nothing deep or mind-blowing, together with bright pretty art and nice writing the final result is quite worthy of spending several hours in a relaxing atmosphere.

review:
[i]Space Live - Advent of the Net Idols[/i] is a futuristic/Japanese idol visual novel that tells us how humanity has abandoned reality and now everyone lives in a digital world. This new future is divided into five factions and each one has an â€œidolâ€ to represent them. Every four years thereâ€™s a competition between those girls to see which faction will prevail and win more followers, and that competition is a simple â€œidol contestâ€ where millions of people will watch and cheer up for them.

First off, there are a few important things I feel like pointing out before sharing my thoughts on Space Live; this is a [b]kinetic novel[/b], meaning that there are no choices to make, you only read the story. There is an interesting point tho: [i]there are no male or female potential partners here, youâ€™ll see the girls and ONLY them interacting directly[/i]. Thereâ€™s a part near the ending a bit different, but the main focus of this novel isnâ€™t the romance between the girls and a male/female reader. I found that aspect enjoyable to be honest. The last thing is that [i]this title is completely unvoiced[/i]. Usually, I don't mind that all. But I could feel myself wanting this VN to be voiced... The characters sing a lot and are very charismatic, so having to play this game unvoiced kinda ruined the fun in my opinion.

From what I could understand, each girl's design is based on a web browser: most scenes happen from the point of view of Ai E  (Internet Explorer), from Macro Space. She's a sweet girl, a bit like your clichÃ© protagonist anime girl; we then meet Sarifa (Safari), a very classy [spoiler]and busty[/spoiler] lady from Ai Space. She looks pretty confident, but she has a cute side; G Chrome (Google Chrome) from Goggle Space is our next idol, she looks cute but rarely shows sign of any other expression other than her usual "blank face"; At the contest, we get to know Higitsune (Firefox) from Mosaic Space, a short[spoiler](heh)[/spoiler]tempered fox girl that really wants to win the idol contest. She's haughty, I usually dislike characters like that, but for some reason she became my favorite; And then there's Tsukikage (Lunascape) from Luna Space. It seems like a current joke in the game that people aren't very interested in her (at least the host of the contest isn't since he never asks her many questions and he's very quick to ditch her lol). 

I could say that there are five chapters according to the challenges that the girls must face: a singing contest, a swimsuit contest [spoiler](which by the way shows a bit of uncensored nip slip)[/spoiler], a "costumes and confessions" (kinda like a theatre), a race, and finally, a "final battle". The third chapter has the closest description of a "romance" that the reader could experience in the novel. About the technical details, the art style is amazing! The developers are the same from other great titles like [b]Da Capo[/b] and [b]Dal Segno[/b]. BGM was cute and catchy, but it got repetitive after a while. It also took me almost four hours to read the entire novel.

6/10. I highly recommend getting this title on a 50% off sale since it looks expensive for a game that begs to be voiced and it isn't. Overall, Space Live is a cute and generic visual novel that might be the right choice if you're in the mood to read something simple and that has its share of fanservice. [spoiler]There's no R18 patch here, meaning that this is the official version of the game.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970494194', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1520052301}
review:
5/10 â€“ Vapid story of idols in a virtual reality future. Multiple pacing problems. All in all, a short kenetic visual novel not worth the price of admission. The game is not suitable for all ages, there is a short scene about a third of the way into the game where the breast/s of three of the characters become fully exposed.  Overall, I cannot recommend this game. If it was free-to-play or less than $5 I would. For $10 however there are much better VN games already on Steam.
The only real reason to play this game is if you really liked the character designs. However, the lack of any animation â€“ particularly given the advent of middleware like Live2D and E-mote. As well as the lack of any VA. You would have to REALLY like the designs for this to be worth your time.

This is a mostly competent VN game, with an obviously excellent team behind it. However, it is also quite obviously a rapidly made cash-in filler project. The only real selling point is that it is an â€œEnglish-first Japanese visual novelâ€ coming from a reputable company (Circus). However, it doesnâ€™t capitalise upon this. It may have had a purpose for learning Japanese, but there is no way to switch languages on the fly (indeed until recently there werenâ€™t any other languages to even switch to; Japanese still remains MIA).

The character designs are decent, and the character art is excellent, remaining on model at all times. Apart from that it is extremely cheap. There is no animation to any of the characters, and more than once the CG image outstays its welcome, frequently the game text describing things happening that donâ€™t get shown in the CG. The backgrounds tend to be drab, generic, and none were standout. The music is likewise forgettable, consisting solely of dull instrumental numbers that rarely even get noticed, except when they donâ€™t really match the on-screen action. The few sound effects are quite literally crap, some actually painful to hear.

The story remains simple and acts solely as a vehicle to give the characters an excuse to change costumes. Five girls, â€œidolsâ€ for their virtual reality space, come together in competition to find out who the best girl is. They are essentially blank slates, you learn nothing of their background or character apart from generic stereotypes. Indeed apart from the brief introduction with Ai E, there are no scenes about the idols lives apart from the competition at the "Space Live". The only thing adding any sort of â€œdepthâ€ to their character, if you would like to call it that, is that they are all very obviously modelled after current web browsers. Ai E â€“ represents Windows IE and Edge. G Chrome is painfully obvious. Higitsune â€“ Mozilla Firefox. Sarifa â€“ Apple Safari. And finally, the less obvious Tsukikage â€“ represents the web browser Lunascape, which very few will have even heard of. (But it is Japanese so I guess they decided they needed a Japanese representative in there?) Now if the VN had capitalised on this personification of browsers, there may have been something worthwhile here, the story though doesnâ€™t use it as a basis of anything except to make a number of cheap gags about Google and surveillance, as well as a sequence involving â€œvirusesâ€ and â€œbugsâ€. In addition there are inconsistencies with the representation, for instance both Tsukikage and Higitsune are presented as â€œnewcomer idolsâ€, yet the browsers they represent are actually older than Chrome and Safari who are represented as veteran idols which was odd.

Speaking of inconsistencies, the game is rife with them. Several moments the description of what is happening in the text does not represent the image on screen at all. An obvious one right near the beginning about G Chromeâ€™s hair colour. It demonstrates a definite lack of care or thought going into the game design, and how rapidly made the game was. Furthermore, the story suffers from a definite lack of pacing or interest. Midway through the game, perhaps recognising that they had no story, they have inserted a sequence of scenes where the idols must produce an acted romantic scene using different scenarios. This long outstays its welcome given all the scenes prior had been short and to the point, and adds nothing to the overall story as the scenarios are completely irrelevant to the actual story of the game. Bizarrely the game text also gives the characters internal monologues for these scenes, which does not make any sense in how the monologues would actually be occurring in the game world.

So to finish up... well... best girl is Ai E!?

review:
Okay this is a tale of the future. By 2222, humanity has decided that reality just isn't worth it, so they have uploaded their consciousnesses into "NetSpace" which is a virtual reality where you can do whatever you like. Unfortunately, lacking structure... or community, communities of their own started to bind together... amusingly communities that bear similarities to modern browers, like IE/Edge, Firefox, Chrome, and Lunascape.

Now every four years a competition occurs to see who rules it all.

This is a kinetic novel, having no choices. There aren't any real risque material, other than... a couple wardrobe malfunctions...

Still, it is a nice tale, and a bit fun.

Would suggest getting it on discount, though.
